Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Historical Geographic Information System (NHGIS) is the nation's most comprehensive source for statistical data, geographic data, and metadata describing spatial characteristics of the American population from 1790 to the present. With 265 billion data points, NHGIS is the largest publicly accessible social science database in the world and is used by thousands of researchers. This project will implement four major improvements to the infrastructure of NHGIS. NHGIS will create data tables for the 1790-1940 decennial censuses from a massive new individual-level database. The project will develop new GIS data identifying locations of incorporated places and MCDs for the 1790-1970 censuses. Census unit boundaries frequently change from one census to the next, making it difficult to analyze population changes over time and space. NHGIS will interpolate census statistics from 1980, 1990, and 2000 and the American Community Survey to produce estimates for 2010 census areas at several geographic levels, including census tracts, places, county subdivisions, and metropolitan areas. Finally, the project will sustain and expand NHGIS education and outreach efforts, offering individual user support and in-person workshops, online tutorials, and web-based community tools.

NHGIS democratizes access to the census, the fundamental source of data about the U.S. population. The proposed improvements will be used for academic research and also for social science training, journalism, policy research at the state and local levels, and private sector research. This infrastructure will allow thousands of investigators in disciplines from economics and ecology to environmental and health policy to address changes across the broad sweep of time at fine levels of spatial organization. NHGIS provides a unique laboratory for the spatial analysis of economic and social processes and offers the empirical foundation needed for developing and testing models of society. Creating new spatiotemporal data for the period 1790 through 1940 will open new opportunities to investigate profound social and economic transformations of American society, including industrialization, immigration, westward migration, and urbanization. Small-area census data are the primary source for investigating such critical issues as suburbanization, the decline and rebirth of central cities, residential segregation, immigrant settlement patterns, rural depopulation, agricultural consolidation, and population shifts from the rust belt to the Sunbelt. The improvements to NHGIS will allow researchers to apply new and powerful approaches to familiar problems by broadening the scope of local and regional analyses to explore variations across time and space simultaneously.

POR.DRECONTENT:
IPUMS NHGIS is the de facto data access and service platform for historical census data no longer available from the US Census Bureau or are difficult to use. We are the creator and disseminator of a unique set of GIS shapefiles depicting historical states/territories, counties, census tract, incorporated places, and minor civil divisions. During the grant period (August 1, 2013 to July 31, 2019), IPUMS NHGIS delivered more than 200,000 datasets to more than 30,000 users.

NHGIS created and disseminated four new datasets as a result of this NSF grant. Using maps and data from US Census Bureau print volumes, we created point-based mapping files that depict the geographic locations of incorporated, unincorporated, and census-designated places from 1900 to the present. These datasets allow users to visualize changes in the spatial configuration of legal units throughout the United States.  Next, we created geographically standardized time series tables that link together comparable statistics from 1990, 2000, and 2010, and standardizes 1990 and 2000 census data to 2010 census units (e.g., counties, cities, county subdivisions, census tracts, census block groups). We used 1990 and 2000 census blocks, the smallest geographic unit for which the Census Bureau publishes data, as the basis for our standardization. Using census blocks yields more accurate estimates than census tracts or other units because nest well within 2010 census units. We published 109 geographically standardized time series tables for 10 geographic levels.

In addition to our estimates of 1990 and 2000 census statistics for 2010 census units, we also provide upper and lower bounds for each estimate. These upper and lower bounds provide users with a measurement of fitness-for-use. If the bounds are too large, users may choose to or not to use the estimates. IPUMS NHGIS is the only standardized data creator to provide such bounds.

The third new dataset we published was a crosswalk linking 1990 and 2000 census blocks to 2010 census blocks. This crosswalk allows users to create geographically standardized data based on NHGIS model. Crosswalks, such as ours, provide flexibility to users, especially those who need particular time series for their research.

The fourth new dataset we published was a set of agricultural census data from 1920, 1925, 1930 and 1935. This dataset contains more than 3,000 variables organized in 594 tables and is available for the nation, states, and counties. Topics in this dataset include land use, crop acreage and production, animal and animal products, farm implements, and fertilizer use and application.

Finally, NHGIS provided high quality user support to hundreds of users during the grant period. We answered questions related to geographically standardized time series tables, the content of contemporary and historical census data, and how to find those data in our access system.

Funding provided by the National Science Foundation allowed IPUMS NHGIS to continue fulfilling its mission of providing high quality spatiotemporal census data to thousands of users throughout the world. We were able to add three new datasets to our data access system and continue supporting users.
